program codeforces_131_b

  implicit none

  integer :: n, i, x
  integer(8), dimension(0:20) :: cnt ! Array to hold counts. Starts 0
  integer(8) :: res

  cnt = 0  ! Initialize all to zero

  read *, n

      read *, x
      ! Calculate the index
      cnt(x+10) = cnt(x+10) + 1
  enddo

  res = 0
  ! first loop from i=0 to 9 (inclusive)

  enddo

  ! add cases where the number x is 0 (counted in index 10)
  res = res + ( cnt(10)*(cnt(10)-1) )/2

  print *, res

end program codeforces_131_b

Another point: in Fortran, the "res" variable must be initialized to zero. In the code above, yes, it's set to 0.

Possible typos or issues:

- Index from 0 to 20 requires the array to be declared from 0 to 20. So in the code, "dimension(0:20)" is important.

- Calculate x +10, which is stored as the index. So if x is -10, gives 0.

Fortran uses 1-based index as default, so array starts at 0 only when declared. The code is okay.

In Fortran, the default integer in the code may be different, but if the variable res is declared as integer(8) (64-bit) then it's okay.

So I think the code is correct as written above.
